column2: The other occupant of the wagon was a man between sixty-five and seventy, with iron-gray hair, a long, full, gray beard, a harsh-featured face, and deep-set hazel eyes under bushy, bristling brows.
column3: The other occupant of the wagon was a man between sixty five and seventy, with iron gray hair, a long, full, gray beard, a harsh featured face, and deep set hazel eyes under bushy, bristling brows.

column2: He was evidently tall, with a spare, ungainly figure, and stooping shoulders. His mouth was close-lipped and relentless, and did not look as if it had ever smiled.
column3: He was evidently tall, with a spare, ungainly figure, and stooping shoulders. His mouth was close lipped and relentless, and did not look as if it had ever smiled.

column2: Indeed, the idea of smiling could not be connected with this man--it was utterly incongruous.
column3: Indeed, the idea of smiling could not be connected with this man-it was utterly incongruous.

column2: Yet there was nothing repellent about his face; and there was something in it that compelled Eric's attention.
column3: Yet there was nothing repellent about his face; and there was something in it that compelled Eric's attention.

column2: He rather prided himself on being a student of physiognomy, and he felt quite sure that this man was no ordinary Lindsay farmer of the genial, garrulous type with which he was familiar.
column3: He rather prided himself on being a student of physiognomy, and he felt quite sure that this man was no ordinary Lindsay farmer of the genial, garrulous type with which he was familiar.

column2: Long after the old wagon, with its oddly assorted pair, had gone lumbering up the hill, Eric found himself thinking of the stern, heavy browed man and the black-eyed, red-lipped boy.
column3: Long after the old wagon, with its oddly assorted pair, had gone lumbering up the hill, Eric found himself thinking of the stern, heavy browed man and the black eyed, red lipped boy.

column2: CHAPTER IV.
column3: CHAPTER four.

column2: A TEA TABLE CONVERSATION
column3: A TEA TABLE CONVERSATION

column2: The Williamson place, where Eric boarded, was on the crest of the succeeding hill.
column3: The Williamson place, where Eric boarded, was on the crest of the succeeding hill.

column2: He liked it as well as Larry West had prophesied that he would.
column3: He liked it as well as Larry West had prophesied that he would.

column2: The Williamsons, as well as the rest of the Lindsay people, took it for granted that he was a poor college student working his way through as Larry West had been doing.
column3: The Williamsons, as well as the rest of the Lindsay people, took it for granted that he was a poor college student working his way through as Larry West had been doing.

column2: Eric did not disturb this belief, although he said nothing to contribute to it.
column3: Eric did not disturb this belief, although he said nothing to contribute to it.

column2: The Williamsons were at tea in the kitchen when Eric went in.
column3: The Williamsons were at tea in the kitchen when Eric went in.

column2: Mrs. Williamson was the "saint in spectacles and calico" which Larry West had termed her.
column3: mrs Williamson was the "saint in spectacles and calico" which Larry West had termed her.

column2: Eric liked her greatly.
column3: Eric liked her greatly.

column2: She was a slight, gray-haired woman, with a thin, sweet, high-bred face, deeply lined with the records of outlived pain.
column3: She was a slight, gray haired woman, with a thin, sweet, high bred face, deeply lined with the records of outlived pain.

column2: She talked little as a rule; but, in the pungent country phrase she never spoke but she said something.
column3: She talked little as a rule; but, in the pungent country phrase she never spoke but she said something.

column2: The one thing that constantly puzzled Eric was how such a woman ever came to marry Robert Williamson.
column3: The one thing that constantly puzzled Eric was how such a woman ever came to marry Robert Williamson.

column2: She smiled in a motherly fashion at Eric, as he hung his hat on the white-washed wall and took his place at the table.
column3: She smiled in a motherly fashion at Eric, as he hung his hat on the white washed wall and took his place at the table.

column2: Outside of the window behind him was a birch grove which, in the westering sun, was a tremulous splendour, with a sea of undergrowth wavered into golden billows by every passing wind.
column3: Outside of the window behind him was a birch grove which, in the westering sun, was a tremulous splendour, with a sea of undergrowth wavered into golden billows by every passing wind.

column2: Old Robert Williamson sat opposite him, on a bench.
column3: Old Robert Williamson sat opposite him, on a bench.

column2: He was a small, lean old man, half lost in loose clothes that seemed far too large for him. When he spoke his voice was as thin and squeaky as he appeared to be himself.
column3: He was a small, lean old man, half lost in loose clothes that seemed far too large for him. When he spoke his voice was as thin and squeaky as he appeared to be himself.

column2: The other end of the bench was occupied by Timothy, sleek and complacent, with a snowy breast and white paws.
column3: The other end of the bench was occupied by Timothy, sleek and complacent, with a snowy breast and white paws.

column2: After old Robert had taken a mouthful of anything he gave a piece to Timothy, who ate it daintily and purred resonant gratitude.
column3: After old Robert had taken a mouthful of anything he gave a piece to Timothy, who ate it daintily and purred resonant gratitude.

column2: You see we're busy waiting for you, Master, said old Robert.
column3: You see we're busy waiting for you, Master, said old Robert.

column2: You're late this evening.	You're late this evening.
column3: true

column2: Keep any of the youngsters in?
column3: Keep any of the youngsters in?

column2: That's a foolish way of punishing them, as hard on yourself as on them.
column3: That's a foolish way of punishing them, as hard on yourself as on them.

column2: One teacher we had four years ago used to lock them in and go home.
column3: One teacher we had four years ago used to lock them in and go home.

column2: Then he'd go back in an hour and let them out--if they were there.
column3: Then he'd go back in an hour and let them out-if they were there.

column2: They weren't always.
column3: They weren't always.

column2: Tom Ferguson kicked the panels out of the old door once and got out that way.
column3: Tom Ferguson kicked the panels out of the old door once and got out that way.

column2: We put a new door of double plank in that they couldn't kick out."
column3: We put a new door of double plank in that they couldn't kick out."

column2: I stayed in the schoolroom to do some work, said Eric briefly.
column3: I stayed in the schoolroom to do some work, said Eric briefly.

column2: Well, you've missed Alexander Tracy.	Well, you've missed Alexander Tracy.
column3: true

column2: He was here to find out if you could play checkers, and, when I told him you could, he left word for you to go up and have a game some evening soon.
column3: He was here to find out if you could play checkers, and, when I told him you could, he left word for you to go up and have a game some evening soon.

column2: Don't beat him too often, even if you can.
column3: Don't beat him too often, even if you can.

column2: You'll need to stand in with him, I tell you, Master, for he's got a son that may brew trouble for you when he starts in to go to school.
column3: You'll need to stand in with him, I tell you, Master, for he's got a son that may brew trouble for you when he starts in to go to school.

column2: Seth Tracy's a young imp, and he'd far sooner be in mischief than eat.
column3: Seth Tracy's a young imp, and he'd far sooner be in mischief than eat.

column2: He tries to run on every new teacher and he's run two clean out of the school.
column3: He tries to run on every new teacher and he's run two clean out of the school.

column2: But he met his match in Mr. West.
column3: But he met his match in mr West.

column2: William Tracy's boys now--you won't have a scrap of bother with THEM.
column3: William Tracy's boys now-you won't have a scrap of bother with THEM.

column2: They're always good because their mother tells them every Sunday that they'll go straight to hell if they don't behave in school.
column3: They're always good because their mother tells them every Sunday that they'll go straight to hell if they don't behave in school.

column2: It's effective.
column3: It's effective.

column2: Take some preserve, Master.
column3: Take some preserve, Master.

column2: You know we don't help things here the way Mrs. Adam Scott does when she has boarders, 'I s'pose you don't want any of this--nor you--nor you?' Mother, Aleck says old George Wright is having the time of his life.
column3: You know we don't help things here the way mrs Adam Scott does when she has boarders, 'I s'pose you don't want any of this-nor you-nor you?' Mother, Aleck says old George Wright is having the time of his life.

column2: His wife has gone to Charlottetown to visit her sister and he is his own boss for the first time since he was married, forty years ago.
column3: His wife has gone to Charlottetown to visit her sister and he is his own boss for the first time since he was married, forty years ago.

column2: He's on a regular orgy, Aleck says.
column3: He's on a regular orgy, Aleck says.

column2: He smokes in the parlour and sits up till eleven o'clock reading dime novels."
column3: He smokes in the parlour and sits up till eleven o'clock reading dime novels."

column2: Perhaps I met Mr. Tracy, said Eric.
column3: Perhaps I met mr Tracy, said Eric.

column2: Is he a tall man, with gray hair and a dark, stern face?
column3: Is he a tall man, with gray hair and a dark, stern face?

column2: No, he's a round, jolly fellow, is Aleck, and he stopped growing pretty much before he'd ever begun.	No, he's a round, jolly fellow, is Aleck, and he stopped growing pretty much before he'd ever begun.
column3: true

column2: I reckon the man you mean is Thomas Gordon. I seen him driving down the road too.
column3: I reckon the man you mean is Thomas Gordon. I seen him driving down the road too.

column2: HE won't be troubling you with invitations up, small fear of it.
column3: HE won't be troubling you with invitations up, small fear of it.

column2: The Gordons ain't sociable, to say the least of it.
column3: The Gordons ain't sociable, to say the least of it.

column2: No, sir!
column3: No, sir!

column2: Mother, pass the biscuits to the Master."
column3: Mother, pass the biscuits to the Master."

column2: Who was the young fellow he had with him? asked Eric curiously.
column3: Who was the young fellow he had with him? asked Eric curiously.

column2: Neil--Neil Gordon.
column3: Neil-Neil Gordon.

column2: That is a Scotchy name for such a face and eyes.	That is a Scotchy name for such a face and eyes.
column3: true

column2: I should rather have expected Guiseppe or Angelo.
column3: I should rather have expected Guiseppe or Angelo.

column2: The boy looks like an Italian."
column3: The boy looks like an Italian."

column2: Well, now, you know, Master, I reckon it's likely he does, seeing that that's exactly what he is.	Well, now, you know, Master, I reckon it's likely he does, seeing that that's exactly what he is.
column3: true

column2: You've hit the nail square on the head. Italyun, yes, sir!
column3: You've hit the nail square on the head. Italyun, yes, sir!

column2: Rather too much so, I'm thinking, for decent folks' taste."
column3: Rather too much so, I'm thinking, for decent folks' taste."

column2: How has it happened that an Italian boy with a Scotch name is living in a place like Lindsay?
column3: How has it happened that an Italian boy with a Scotch name is living in a place like Lindsay?

column2: Well, Master, it was this way.	Well, Master, it was this way.
column3: true

column2: About twenty-two years ago--WAS it twenty-two, Mother or twenty-four?
column3: About twenty two years ago-WAS it twenty two, Mother or twenty four?

column2: Yes, it was twenty-two--'twas the same year our Jim was born and he'd have been twenty-two if he'd lived, poor little fellow.
column3: Yes, it was twenty two-'twas the same year our Jim was born and he'd have been twenty two if he'd lived, poor little fellow.

column2: Well, Master, twenty-two years ago a couple of Italian pack peddlers came along and called at the Gordon place.
column3: Well, Master, twenty two years ago a couple of Italian pack peddlers came along and called at the Gordon place.

column2: The country was swarming with them then.
column3: The country was swarming with them then.

column2: I useter set the dog on one every day on an average.
column3: I useter set the dog on one every day on an average.

column2: Well, these peddlers were man and wife, and the woman took sick up there at the Gordon place, and Janet Gordon took her in and nursed her. A baby was born the next day, and the woman died.	Well, these peddlers were man and wife, and the woman took sick up there at the Gordon place, and Janet Gordon took her in and nursed her. A baby was born the next day, and the woman died.
column3: true

column2: Then the first thing anybody knew the father skipped clean out, pack and all, and was never seen or heard tell of afterwards.
column3: Then the first thing anybody knew the father skipped clean out, pack and all, and was never seen or heard tell of afterwards.

column2: The Gordons were left with the fine youngster to their hands.
column3: The Gordons were left with the fine youngster to their hands.

column2: Folks advised them to send him to the Orphan Asylum, and 'twould have been the wisest plan, but the Gordons were never fond of taking advice.
column3: Folks advised them to send him to the Orphan Asylum, and 'twould have been the wisest plan, but the Gordons were never fond of taking advice.

column2: Old James Gordon was living then, Thomas and Janet's father, and he said he would never turn a child out of his door.
column3: Old james Gordon was living then, Thomas and Janet's father, and he said he would never turn a child out of his door.

column2: He was a masterful old man and liked to be boss.
column3: He was a masterful old man and liked to be boss.

column2: Folks used to say he had a grudge against the sun 'cause it rose and set without his say so.
column3: Folks used to say he had a grudge against the sun 'cause it rose and set without his say so.

column2: Anyhow, they kept the baby.
column3: Anyhow, they kept the baby.

column2: They called him Neil and had him baptized same as any Christian child.
column3: They called him Neil and had him baptized same as any Christian child.

column2: He's always lived there.
column3: He's always lived there.

column2: They did well enough by him.
column3: They did well enough by him.

column2: He was sent to school and taken to church and treated like one of themselves.
column3: He was sent to school and taken to church and treated like one of themselves.

column2: Some folks think they made too much of him.
column3: Some folks think they made too much of him.

column2: It doesn't always do with that kind, for 'what's bred in bone is mighty apt to come out in flesh,' if 'taint kept down pretty well. Neil's smart and a great worker, they tell me.
column3: It doesn't always do with that kind, for 'what's bred in bone is mighty apt to come out in flesh,' if 'taint kept down pretty well. Neil's smart and a great worker, they tell me.

column2: But folks hereabouts don't like him.
column3: But folks hereabouts don't like him.

column2: They say he ain't to be trusted further'n you can see him, if as far.
column3: They say he ain't to be trusted further'n you can see him, if as far.

column2: It's certain he's awful hot tempered, and one time when he was going to school he near about killed a boy he'd took a spite to--choked him till he was black in the face and Neil had to be dragged off."
column3: It's certain he's awful hot tempered, and one time when he was going to school he near about killed a boy he'd took a spite to-choked him till he was black in the face and Neil had to be dragged off."

column2: Well now, father, you know they teased him terrible, protested Mrs. Williamson.
column3: Well now, father, you know they teased him terrible, protested mrs Williamson.

column2: The poor boy had a real hard time when he went to school, Master.	The poor boy had a real hard time when he went to school, Master.
column3: true

column2: The other children were always casting things up to him and calling him names."
column3: The other children were always casting things up to him and calling him names."

column2: Oh, I daresay they tormented him a lot, admitted her husband.
column3: Oh, I daresay they tormented him a lot, admitted her husband.

column2: He's a great hand at the fiddle and likes company.	He's a great hand at the fiddle and likes company.
column3: true

column2: He goes to the harbour a good deal.
column3: He goes to the harbour a good deal.

column2: But they say he takes sulky spells when he hasn't a word to throw to a dog.
column3: But they say he takes sulky spells when he hasn't a word to throw to a dog.

column2: 'Twouldn't be any wonder, living with the Gordons. They're all as queer as Dick's hat-band."
column3: 'Twouldn't be any wonder, living with the Gordons. They're all as queer as Dick's hat band."

column2: Father, you shouldn't talk so about your neighbours, said his wife rebukingly.
column3: Father, you shouldn't talk so about your neighbours, said his wife rebukingly.

column2: Well now, Mother, you know they are, if you'd only speak up honest.	Well now, Mother, you know they are, if you'd only speak up honest.
column3: true

column2: But you're like old Aunt Nancy Scott, you never say anything uncharitable except in the way of business.
column3: But you're like old Aunt Nancy Scott, you never say anything uncharitable except in the way of business.

column2: You know the Gordons ain't like other people and never were and never will be.
column3: You know the Gordons ain't like other people and never were and never will be.

column2: They're about the only queer folks we have in Lindsay, Master, except old Peter Cook, who keeps twenty-five cats.
column3: They're about the only queer folks we have in Lindsay, Master, except old peter Cook, who keeps twenty five cats.

column2: Lord, Master, think of it!
column3: Lord, Master, think of it!

column2: What chanct would a poor mouse have?
column3: What chanct would a poor mouse have?

column2: None of the rest of us are queer, leastwise, we hain't found it out if we are.
column3: None of the rest of us are queer, leastwise, we hain't found it out if we are.

column2: But, then, we're mighty uninteresting, I'm bound to admit that."
column3: But, then, we're mighty uninteresting, I'm bound to admit that."

column2: Where do the Gordons live? asked Eric, who had grown used to holding fast to a given point of inquiry through all the bewildering mazes of old Robert's conversation.
column3: Where do the Gordons live? asked Eric, who had grown used to holding fast to a given point of inquiry through all the bewildering mazes of old Robert's conversation.

column2: Away up yander, half a mile in from Radnor road, with a thick spruce wood atween them and all the rest of the world.	Away up yander, half a mile in from Radnor road, with a thick spruce wood atween them and all the rest of the world.
column3: false

column2: They never go away anywheres, except to church--they never miss that--and nobody goes there.
column3: They never go away anywheres, except to church-they never miss that-and nobody goes there.

column2: There's just old Thomas, and his sister Janet, and a niece of theirs, and this here Neil we've been talking about.
column3: There's just old Thomas, and his sister Janet, and a niece of theirs, and this here Neil we've been talking about.

column2: They're a queer, dour, cranky lot, and I WILL say it, Mother.
column3: They're a queer, dour, cranky lot, and I WILL say it, Mother.

column2: There, give your old man a cup of tea and never mind the way his tongue runs on.
column3: There, give your old man a cup of tea and never mind the way his tongue runs on.

column2: Speaking of tea, do you know Mrs. Adam Palmer and Mrs. Jim Martin took tea together at Foster Reid's last Wednesday afternoon?"
column3: Speaking of tea, do you know mrs Adam Palmer and mrs Jim Martin took tea together at Foster Reid's last Wednesday afternoon?"

column2: No, why, I thought they were on bad terms, said Mrs. Williamson, betraying a little feminine curiosity.
column3: No, why, I thought they were on bad terms, said mrs Williamson, betraying a little feminine curiosity.

column2: So they are, so they are.	So they are, so they are.
column3: true

column2: But they both happened to visit Mrs. Foster the same afternoon and neither would leave because that would be knuckling down to the other.
column3: But they both happened to visit mrs Foster the same afternoon and neither would leave because that would be knuckling down to the other.

column2: So they stuck it out, on opposite sides of the parlour.
column3: So they stuck it out, on opposite sides of the parlour.

column2: Mrs. Foster says she never spent such an uncomfortable afternoon in all her life before.
column3: mrs Foster says she never spent such an uncomfortable afternoon in all her life before.

column2: She would talk a spell to one and then t'other.
column3: She would talk a spell to one and then t'other.

column2: And they kept talking TO Mrs. Foster and AT each other.
column3: And they kept talking TO mrs Foster and AT each other.

column2: Mrs. Foster says she really thought she'd have to keep them all night, for neither would start to go home afore the other.
column3: mrs Foster says she really thought she'd have to keep them all night, for neither would start to go home afore the other.

column2: Finally Jim Martin came in to look for his wife, 'cause he thought she must have got stuck in the marsh, and that solved the problem.
column3: Finally Jim Martin came in to look for his wife, 'cause he thought she must have got stuck in the marsh, and that solved the problem.

column2: Master, you ain't eating anything.
column3: Master, you ain't eating anything.

column2: Don't mind my stopping; I was at it half an hour afore you come, and anyway I'm in a hurry.
column3: Don't mind my stopping; I was at it half an hour afore you come, and anyway I'm in a hurry.

column2: My hired boy went home to-day.
column3: My hired boy went home to day.

column2: He heard the rooster crow at twelve last night and he's gone home to see which of his family is dead.
column3: He heard the rooster crow at twelve last night and he's gone home to see which of his family is dead.

column2: He knows one of 'em is.
column3: He knows one of 'em is.

column2: He heard a rooster crow in the middle of the night onct afore and the next day he got word that his second cousin down at Souris was dead.
column3: He heard a rooster crow in the middle of the night o n c t afore and the next day he got word that his second cousin down at Souris was dead.

column2: Mother, if the Master don't want any more tea, ain't there some cream for Timothy?"
column3: Mother, if the Master don't want any more tea, ain't there some cream for Timothy?"
